speaker: ROSALIND
text: It is not the fashion to see the lady the

speaker: ROSALIND
text: epilogue, but it is no more unhandsome than to see

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the lord the prologue. If it be true that good wine

speaker: ROSALIND
text: needs no bush, ’tis true that a good play needs no

speaker: ROSALIND
text: epilogue. Yet to good wine they do use good bushes,

speaker: ROSALIND
text: and good plays prove the better by the help of good

speaker: ROSALIND
text: epilogues. What a case am I in then that am neither

speaker: ROSALIND
text: a good epilogue nor cannot insinuate with you in

speaker: ROSALIND
text: the behalf of a good play! I am not furnished like a

speaker: ROSALIND
text: beggar; therefore to beg will not become me. My

speaker: ROSALIND
text: way is to conjure you, and I’ll begin with the

speaker: ROSALIND
text: women. I charge you, O women, for the love you

speaker: ROSALIND
text: bear to men, to like as much of this play as please

speaker: ROSALIND
text: you. And I charge you, O men, for the love you bear

speaker: ROSALIND
text: to women—as I perceive by your simpering, none

speaker: ROSALIND
text: of you hates them—that between you and the

speaker: ROSALIND
text: women the play may please. If I were a woman, I

speaker: ROSALIND
text: would kiss as many of you as had beards that

speaker: ROSALIND
text: pleased me, complexions that liked me, and breaths

speaker: ROSALIND
text: that I defied not. And I am sure as many as have

speaker: ROSALIND
text: good beards, or good faces, or sweet breaths will for

speaker: ROSALIND
text: my kind offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.
